With monitored oxygen transfer rate (OTR) and carbon dioxide transfer rate (CTR), the respiratory quotient (RQ) can serve as an indicator for the current consumed carbon source and much more (Anderlei et al., 2004; Finger et al., 2023; Pastoors et al., 2023). RAMOS is a noninvasive method to monitor the OTR and CTR in shake flasks (Anderlei & Büchs, 2001; Anderlei et al., 2004). To further increase the capabilities of the RAMOS technology, methane transfer rate (MTR) monitoring was added to the RAMOS technology to cultivate methanotrophs while monitoring all gases involved in the process. In this work, the cultivation of methanotrophs in the RAMOS device as well as the MTR capabilities of the RAMOS technology are evaluated with M. capsulatus as a model organism. Different metabolic effects like transfer limitations and growth on atmospheric nitrogen were investigated to show the capabilities of the methane RAMOS technology in observing both biological phenomena, as well as process limitations.

With monitored oxygen transfer rate (OTR) and carbon dioxide transfer rate (CTR), the respiratory quotient (RQ) can serve as an indicator for the current consumed carbon source and much more (Anderlei et al., 2004; Finger et al., 2023; Pastoors et al., 2023). RAMOS is a noninvasive method to monitor the OTR and CTR in shake flasks (Anderlei & Büchs, 2001; Anderlei et al., 2004). To further increase the capabilities of the RAMOS technology, methane transfer rate (MTR) monitoring was added to the RAMOS technology to cultivate methanotrophs while monitoring all gases involved in the process. It allows the screening of methanotrophic bacteria in shake flasks, as well as the optimization of their cultivation conditions and process parameters. In this work, the cultivation of methanotrophs in the RAMOS device as well as the MTR capabilities of the RAMOS technology are evaluated with M. capsulatus as a model organism. Different metabolic effects like transfer limitations and growth on atmospheric nitrogen were investigated to show the capabilities of the methane RAMOS technology in observing both biological phenomena, as well as process limitations.

The OQ describes the ratio of needed O2 to metabolize the consumed CH4 and should give insights into the carbon and energy metabolization of the cultures. Analogous, the CQ is the ratio of consumed and respired carbon in the form of CH4 and CO2 , respectively. CQ can be used to monitor the biomass production and the efficiency of the CH4 metabolization. In this paper, three gases are of importance: O , CH 2 4 , and CO2 . While O2 and CH4 are consumed, CO2 is produced during cultivation processes. The changes of the partial pressures of these gases are reflected in the transfer rates and correlate with the metabolic activity of the bacteria. Transfer rates offer vital insights into the processes by providing information about growth rates, gas transfer limitations and metabolic effects over the course of cultivation. With monitored oxygen transfer rate (OTR) and carbon dioxide transfer rate (CTR), the respiratory quotient (RQ) can serve as an indicator for the current consumed carbon source and much more (Anderlei et al., 2004; Finger et al., 2023; Pastoors et al., 2023). In addition to the transfer rates themselves, the ratios between them can also provide essential information. With the additional CH4 measurements, additional ratios can be calculated: the oxidation quotient (OQ) and the carbon quotient (CQ). The OQ describes the ratio of needed O2 to metabolize the consumed CH4 and should give insights into the carbon and energy metabolization of the cultures. Analogous, the CQ is the ratio of consumed and respired carbon in the form of CH4 and CO2 , respectively. CQ can be used to monitor the biomass production and the efficiency of the CH4 metabolization. This work aims to develop a method to monitor CH4 transfer rates in shake flasks based on the existing Respiration Activity MOnitoring System (RAMOS) technology. RAMOS is a noninvasive method to monitor the OTR and CTR in shake flasks (Anderlei & Büchs, 2001; Anderlei et al., 2004). The technology has been firmly established for screening in shake flasks for both aerobic cultivations, as well as anaerobic cultivations (Mann et al., 2021; Munch et al., 2020). To further increase the capabilities of the RAMOS technology, methane transfer rate (MTR) monitoring was added to the RAMOS technology to cultivate methanotrophs while monitoring all gases involved in the process. This newly extended device will be referred as the methane RAMOS device. It allows the screening of methanotrophic bacteria in shake flasks, as well as the optimization of their cultivation conditions and process parameters. In this work, the cultivation of methanotrophs in the RAMOS device as well as the MTR capabilities of the RAMOS technology are evaluated with M. capsulatus as a model organism. Different metabolic effects like transfer limitations and growth on atmospheric nitrogen were investigated to show the capabilities of the methane RAMOS technology in observing both biological phenomena, as well as process limitations. object_positions.matched_text: gas transfer rates in shake flasks

source_span.text_evidence:
Valve

All cultivations were conducted in the RAMOS device adapted from Schulte et al. (2018), Munch et al. (2020), and Mann et al. (2021) to monitor gas transfer rates in shake flasks. The in -gas entered the temperature -controlled shaker and was distributed over capillaries ( ∅ = 0.1 mm) to ensure a homogeneous gas distribution to all eight flasks. Each flask was connected to a measurement loop containing a piezo -membrane pumps mp6 -gas The gas sensors were combined in a custom 3 -D printed sensor block (DraftGrey) and connected to the measurement loop. During the aeration phases, the flasks are continuously aerated to keep a constant gas composition. The change in gas composition within the headspace of the flasks is used to calculate the transfer rates of the gases. Additionally, the pressure change in the flasks is measured, which is used to calculate the gross gas transfer rate (GGTR). This can be calculated from the total pressure change in the flasks over the measurement phase. The in -gas, controlled by a mass flow controller, is distributed to the eight flasks over capillaries to ensure equal gas distribution between all flasks. Pressure sensors connected to the loop measure the pressure change in the flasks.

Analogous, the ratio of consumed and exhausted carbon, the CQ, can be calculated with Equation (5):

Instead of using pressured air or N2 to aerate the flasks, a gas mixture of O , CH 2 4 , and CO2 was used. An ATEX consideration was performed before cultivation to ensure safe operation of the device. The chosen gas composition was selected to ensure safe operation of the device by guaranteeing it to stay outside of the explosive area of CH4 and air as displayed in Figure 2. The gas was composed of 5.9 vol% CH4 and 3.4 vol% O2 . The blue dot indicates the initial gas composition. In the chart, the red area describes the ATEX state, where O2 is available in excess, as well as CH4 being present within the lower and upper explosive limit. It is to be noted that the lower explosive limit of CH4 (4.4 vol%) is exceeded in the in -gas (CHEMSAFE, 2014; Prendes -Gero et al., 2022). In case of a leakage and the gas is diluted with air, the gas composition moves along the green line. Due to the low O2 concentration below the limiting oxygen concentration of 9.9 vol% O2 , by the time that enough O2 is present, the CH4 concentration is diluted sufficiently to be outside of the explosive area. CO2 with a concentration of 1.3 vol% was added to the in -gas, because it has been reported that an improved growth rate can be observed with an increased CO2 concentration in the in -gas (Henard et al., 2021). Additionally, a co -utilization of CO2 was proposed, which also enhances the growth of methanotrophic organisms (Averesch & Kracke, 2018).

Instead of using pressured air or N2 to aerate the flasks, a gas mixture of O , CH 2 4 , and CO2 was used. An ATEX consideration was performed before cultivation to ensure safe operation of the device. The chosen gas composition was selected to ensure safe operation of the device by guaranteeing it to stay outside of the explosive area of CH4 and air as displayed in Figure 2. The gas was composed of 5.9 vol% CH4 and 3.4 vol% O2 . The blue dot indicates the initial gas composition. In the chart, the red area describes the ATEX state, where O2 is available in excess, as well as CH4 being present within the lower and upper explosive limit. It is to be noted that the lower explosive limit of CH4 (4.4 vol%) is exceeded in the in -gas (CHEMSAFE, 2014; Prendes -Gero et al., 2022). In case of a leakage and the gas is diluted with air, the gas composition moves along the green line. Due to the low O2 concentration below the limiting oxygen concentration of 9.9 vol% O2 , by the time that enough O2 is present, the CH4 concentration is diluted sufficiently to be outside of the explosive area. CO2 with a concentration of 1.3 vol% was added to the in -gas, because it has been reported that an improved growth rate can be observed with an increased CO2 concentration in the in -gas (Henard et al., 2021). Additionally, a co -utilization of CO2 was proposed, which also enhances the growth of methanotrophic organisms (Averesch & Kracke, 2018).

source_span.text_evidence: The measured values for consumed O2 and CH4 and the produced CO2 do not fit the expected growth ratios of 1.45 mol/L CH4 per 1 mol/L O2 and 0.48 mol/L CO2 per 1 mmol/L CH4 (Equation 6) also reported in literature (Geymonat et al., 2011; Whittenbury et al., 1970). Only for the beginning of the cultivation, the ratios are in line with the theoretical values. These ratios seem to apply only for unlimited growth and shift during transfer limited conditions. The subsequent section provides a detailed analysis of the transfer rates and their respective ratios. This section shows that the methane RAMOS device can monitor all relevant transfer rates of M. capsulatus in shake flasks and gas transfer limitations and different transfer rate ratios can be detected.

relations.subject: existing models
relations.predicate: predict a shift in the ratios towards higher O2 consumption during gas transfer limitations and agree with the monitored values as well

source_span.text_evidence:
Methanotrophic microorganisms consume O2 and CH4 and produce CO2 as shown in Equation (6). When considering all gases, the summation of consumed O2 and CH4 , minus the produced CO2 , should precisely match the total gas produced, as outlined in Equation (2). It is defined as the ratio of the produced CO2 and the consumed O2 and gives detailed insights into the metabolism of cultures (García et al., 2020; Heyman et al., 2020; Müller et al., 2018; Romero -Kutzner et al., 2015). The OQ describes the ratio of the consumed O2 to CH4 in the form of their respective transfer rates and should offer similar insights (see Figure 6). These findings are in line with the theoretical values for unlimited growth of 1.45 O2 per CH4 , as described above. Existing models predict a shift in the ratios towards higher O2 consumption during gas transfer limitations and agree with the monitored values as well (Lieven et al., 2018). Slope 1.80

During that time, the cultures consume more O2 per CH4 and the transfer limitation restricts the oxidation of CH4 . The cultures switch away from biomass formation to a more energy -efficient metabolism, which is reflected in the ratio of 1.8 O2 per CH4 . Since the organism would ideally consume the gases in the preferred ratio of 1.45, the fact that this ratio shifts towards a reduced CH4 consumption per O2 shows that O2 is limiting. The available O2 is increasingly used for energy conversion, instead for biomass formation. With further increasing biomass and a stable gas consumption, the O2 per CH4 ration increases further. Towards the end of the cultivation, a ratio slightly above 2.0 O2 per CH4 (see Equation 7) is reached. During the shift into the O2 limitation, the CQ shifts towards a ratio of 0.7. This trend implies that M. capsulatus predominantly respires most of the assimilated carbon as CO2 , rather than utilizing it for biomass or product synthesis.
The CQ supports this as well, with values around 0.5 during the exponential growth phase (Figure S6).
After starting the experiments, the flasks are still filled with air and it takes some time (~1 h) for an equilibrium to be reached within the headspace.

The initial values cluster slightly above an OQ of 1.45 for OTR values below 10 mmol/L/h during the exponential growth phase of the cultures. At higher OTR values above 10 mmol/L/h, the OQ shifts towards 1.8, indicating a change in metabolism in the cultures.

To investigate the nitrogen fixation capabilities of M. capsulatus and further validate the methane RAMOS device, the nitrogen concentrations in the medium were varied from 0% to 100% of the default concentration of 1 g/L KNO3 . Regardless of the supplied nitrogen concentration, all cultures exhibit growth, as indicated by increasing transfer rates. The data demonstrates that M. capsulatus can grow without KNO3 being present in the medium by fixing nitrogen from the atmosphere.

The OQ describes the ratio of needed O2 to metabolize the consumed CH4 and should give insights into the carbon and energy metabolization of the cultures. With monitored oxygen transfer rate (OTR) and carbon dioxide transfer rate (CTR), the respiratory quotient (RQ) can serve as an indicator for the current consumed carbon source and much more (Anderlei et al., 2004; Finger et al., 2023; Pastoors et al., 2023). RAMOS is a noninvasive method to monitor the OTR and CTR in shake flasks (Anderlei & Büchs, 2001; Anderlei et al., 2004). To further increase the capabilities of the RAMOS technology, methane transfer rate (MTR) monitoring was added to the RAMOS technology to cultivate methanotrophs while monitoring all gases involved in the process. It allows the screening of methanotrophic bacteria in shake flasks, as well as the optimization of their cultivation conditions and process parameters. In this work, the cultivation of methanotrophs in the RAMOS device as well as the MTR capabilities of the RAMOS technology are evaluated with M. capsulatus as a model organism. Different metabolic effects like transfer limitations and growth on atmospheric nitrogen were investigated to show the capabilities of the methane RAMOS technology in observing both biological phenomena, as well as process limitations.

With the additional CH4 measurements, additional ratios can be calculated: the oxidation quotient (OQ) and the carbon quotient (CQ). The OQ describes the ratio of needed O2 to metabolize the consumed CH4 and should give insights into the carbon and energy metabolization of the cultures. Analogous, the CQ is the ratio of consumed and respired carbon in the form of CH4 and CO2 , respectively. CQ can be used to monitor the biomass production and the efficiency of the CH4 metabolization. In this paper, three gases are of importance: O , CH 2 4 , and CO2 . While O2 and CH4 are consumed, CO2 is produced during cultivation processes. The changes of the partial pressures of these gases are reflected in the transfer rates and correlate with the metabolic activity of the bacteria. Transfer rates offer vital insights into the processes by providing information about growth rates, gas transfer limitations and metabolic effects over the course of cultivation. With monitored oxygen transfer rate (OTR) and carbon dioxide transfer rate (CTR), the respiratory quotient (RQ) can serve as an indicator for the current consumed carbon source and much more (Anderlei et al., 2004; Finger et al., 2023; Pastoors et al., 2023). In addition to the transfer rates themselves, the ratios between them can also provide essential information. With the additional CH4 measurements, additional ratios can be calculated: the oxidation quotient (OQ) and the carbon quotient (CQ). The OQ describes the ratio of needed O2 to metabolize the consumed CH4 and should give insights into the carbon and energy metabolization of the cultures. Analogous, the CQ is the ratio of consumed and respired carbon in the form of CH4 and CO2 , respectively. CQ can be used to monitor the biomass production and the efficiency of the CH4 metabolization. This work aims to develop a method to monitor CH4 transfer rates in shake flasks based on the existing Respiration Activity MOnitoring System (RAMOS) technology. RAMOS is a noninvasive method to monitor the OTR and CTR in shake flasks (Anderlei & Büchs, 2001; Anderlei et al., 2004). The technology has been firmly established for screening in shake flasks for both aerobic cultivations, as well as anaerobic cultivations (Mann et al., 2021; Munch et al., 2020). To further increase the capabilities of the RAMOS technology, methane transfer rate (MTR) monitoring was added to the RAMOS technology to cultivate methanotrophs while monitoring all gases involved in the process. This newly extended device will be referred as the methane RAMOS device. It allows the screening of methanotrophic bacteria in shake flasks, as well as the optimization of their cultivation conditions and process parameters. In this work, the cultivation of methanotrophs in the RAMOS device as well as the MTR capabilities of the RAMOS technology are evaluated with M. capsulatus as a model organism. Different metabolic effects like transfer limitations and growth on atmospheric nitrogen were investigated to show the capabilities of the methane RAMOS technology in observing both biological phenomena, as well as process limitations. source_span.text_evidence:
Valve

All cultivations were conducted in the RAMOS device adapted from Schulte et al. (2018), Munch et al. (2020), and Mann et al. (2021) to monitor gas transfer rates in shake flasks. The in -gas entered the temperature -controlled shaker and was distributed over capillaries ( ∅ = 0.1 mm) to ensure a homogeneous gas distribution to all eight flasks. Each flask was connected to a measurement loop containing a piezo -membrane pumps mp6 -gas The gas sensors were combined in a custom 3 -D printed sensor block (DraftGrey) and connected to the measurement loop. During the aeration phases, the flasks are continuously aerated to keep a constant gas composition. The change in gas composition within the headspace of the flasks is used to calculate the transfer rates of the gases. Additionally, the pressure change in the flasks is measured, which is used to calculate the gross gas transfer rate (GGTR). This can be calculated from the total pressure change in the flasks over the measurement phase. The in -gas, controlled by a mass flow controller, is distributed to the eight flasks over capillaries to ensure equal gas distribution between all flasks. Pressure sensors connected to the loop measure the pressure change in the flasks.

Instead of using pressured air or N2 to aerate the flasks, a gas mixture of O , CH 2 4 , and CO2 was used. An ATEX consideration was performed before cultivation to ensure safe operation of the device. The chosen gas composition was selected to ensure safe operation of the device by guaranteeing it to stay outside of the explosive area of CH4 and air as displayed in Figure 2. The gas was composed of 5.9 vol% CH4 and 3.4 vol% O2 . The blue dot indicates the initial gas composition. In the chart, the red area describes the ATEX state, where O2 is available in excess, as well as CH4 being present within the lower and upper explosive limit. It is to be noted that the lower explosive limit of CH4 (4.4 vol%) is exceeded in the in -gas (CHEMSAFE, 2014; Prendes -Gero et al., 2022). In case of a leakage and the gas is diluted with air, the gas composition moves along the green line. Due to the low O2 concentration below the limiting oxygen concentration of 9.9 vol% O2 , by the time that enough O2 is present, the CH4 concentration is diluted sufficiently to be outside of the explosive area. CO2 with a concentration of 1.3 vol% was added to the in -gas, because it has been reported that an improved growth rate can be observed with an increased CO2 concentration in the in -gas (Henard et al., 2021). Additionally, a co -utilization of CO2 was proposed, which also enhances the growth of methanotrophic organisms (Averesch & Kracke, 2018).

The gas was composed of 5.9 vol% CH4 and 3.4 vol% O2 . The blue dot indicates the initial gas composition. In the chart, the red area describes the ATEX state, where O2 is available in excess, as well as CH4 being present within the lower and upper explosive limit. It is to be noted that the lower explosive limit of CH4 (4.4 vol%) is exceeded in the in -gas (CHEMSAFE, 2014; Prendes -Gero et al., 2022). In case of a leakage and the gas is diluted with air, the gas composition moves along the green line. Due to the low O2 concentration below the limiting oxygen concentration of 9.9 vol% O2 , by the time that enough O2 is present, the CH4 concentration is diluted sufficiently to be outside of the explosive area. CO2 with a concentration of 1.3 vol% was added to the in -gas, because it has been reported that an improved growth rate can be observed with an increased CO2 concentration in the in -gas (Henard et al., 2021). Additionally, a co -utilization of CO2 was proposed, which also enhances the growth of methanotrophic organisms (Averesch & Kracke, 2018).

The maximum methane transfer rate ( MTRmax ) was calculated from the maximum oxygen transfer rate ( OTRmax ) values with a fudge factor of 0.855 to account for the differences in solubility and gas transition coefficients (Equation 3) reported in literature (Cussler, 2009; Ghaz -Jahanian et al., 2018; Meier et al., 2016; Yu et al., 2006).

all_relations.subject: existing models
all_relations.predicate: predict a shift in the ratios towards higher O2 consumption during gas transfer limitations and agree with the monitored values as well

source_span.text_evidence:
Methanotrophic microorganisms consume O2 and CH4 and produce CO2 as shown in Equation (6). When considering all gases, the summation of consumed O2 and CH4 , minus the produced CO2 , should precisely match the total gas produced, as outlined in Equation (2). It is defined as the ratio of the produced CO2 and the consumed O2 and gives detailed insights into the metabolism of cultures (García et al., 2020; Heyman et al., 2020; Müller et al., 2018; Romero -Kutzner et al., 2015). The OQ describes the ratio of the consumed O2 to CH4 in the form of their respective transfer rates and should offer similar insights (see Figure 6). These findings are in line with the theoretical values for unlimited growth of 1.45 O2 per CH4 , as described above. Existing models predict a shift in the ratios towards higher O2 consumption during gas transfer limitations and agree with the monitored values as well (Lieven et al., 2018). Slope 1.80

During that time, the cultures consume more O2 per CH4 and the transfer limitation restricts the oxidation of CH4 . The cultures switch away from biomass formation to a more energy -efficient metabolism, which is reflected in the ratio of 1.8 O2 per CH4 . Since the organism would ideally consume the gases in the preferred ratio of 1.45, the fact that this ratio shifts towards a reduced CH4 consumption per O2 shows that O2 is limiting. The available O2 is increasingly used for energy conversion, instead for biomass formation. With further increasing biomass and a stable gas consumption, the O2 per CH4 ration increases further. Towards the end of the cultivation, a ratio slightly above 2.0 O2 per CH4 (see Equation 7) is reached. During the shift into the O2 limitation, the CQ shifts towards a ratio of 0.7. This trend implies that M. capsulatus predominantly respires most of the assimilated carbon as CO2 , rather than utilizing it for biomass or product synthesis.
The CQ supports this as well, with values around 0.5 during the exponential growth phase (Figure S6).
After starting the experiments, the flasks are still filled with air and it takes some time (~1 h) for an equilibrium to be reached within the headspace.

To investigate the nitrogen fixation capabilities of M. capsulatus and further validate the methane RAMOS device, the nitrogen concentrations in the medium were varied from 0% to 100% of the default concentration of 1 g/L KNO3 . Regardless of the supplied nitrogen concentration, all cultures exhibit growth, as indicated by increasing transfer rates. The data demonstrates that M. capsulatus can grow without KNO3 being present in the medium by fixing nitrogen from the atmosphere.
